The seventy-one year old institution, which is located in the Old City of Bethlehem, is currently closed due to the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, and is currently facing a $1 million deficit.The center is currently receiving about $25 million in funding from the Israeli government and from various Palestinian organizations, and has been working to raise $100 million to revitalize the center and expand its art collection. The facility has been a site of cultural exchange between the Palestinian people and Israel for more than sixty years. In 1997, the center was renovated and renamed the Peace Research Institute (PRI). The institution received a gift of two hundred works, including forty-six by Yasir Arafat and forty-six works by Palestinian artists’ families.In 2017, the Israeli government approved a $13 million grant to PRI for its redesign and renovation, and in 2018, the ministry of education and culture approved a $15 million donation

The twenty-three-year-old American artist, who takes inspiration from her childhood in rural Pennsylvania, has won the $50,000 New York City Innovations Award. The $75,000 award was established in 2016 to support artists who are making transformative artistic contributions to the city. The 2019 winners, which were selected by a group of curators and arts writers, are Stacey Schoenfeld, Ariel Zambelich, Andrea Hilti, Andrea Lazzara, Andrea Mack, Alexander Oehlen, and Alexandra Steiner.

The next Biennial should be held in 2021 and will take up issues such as the art and social practices of Los Angeles, the disappearance of African-American art in the United States, and the impact of climate change. The upcoming edition will take place in March.


Part of an international project to assess the spatial extent and the structural characteristics of Israel’s occupied West Bank territories, the exhibition “Palestinians in the Walls” was staged at the Union Museum in Jerusalem. The event was curated by Amana Jumay and took place at the end of a two-week exhibition, “From Walls to Walls: Inside the Art of Israeli Occupation.” Organized by Arts Council, the project was curated by Omer Bar-Lev and consists of twenty-one images, sixteen installations, two videos, an audio-visual work, and a performance.“Palestinians in the Walls” is a multi-dimensional historical narrative.
